conclusion: The p-V diagram shows the process of an ideal gas from state A to state B and then to state C.
The temperature of the gas at state A is 27°C, which is 300 K.
The p-V diagram is a graph of pressure (p) against volume (V) for an ideal gas.
From state A to state B, the gas expands from a volume of 10^-3 m^3 to 2.5 x 10^-3 m^3.
The volume increases by a factor of 2.5.
The pressure remains constant at 3 x 10^-5 Pa from state A to state B.
From state B to state C, the gas expands from a volume of 2.5 x 10^-3 m^3 to 3 x 10^-3 m^3.
The volume increases by a factor of 1.25.
The pressure remains constant at 3 x 10^-5 Pa from state B to state C.
The work done by the gas is the change in internal energy of the gas.
The internal energy of an ideal gas is given by the equation U = nRT, where n is the number of moles of gas, R is the ideal gas constant, and T is the temperature of the gas.
The change in internal energy of the gas from state A to state B is calculated as ΔU_A = nRT_A - nRT_B = (2.5 x 10^-3 m^3)(3 x 10^-5 Pa)(300 K) - (1 x 10^-3 m^3)(3 x 10^-5 Pa)(27°C) = 1.5 x 10^-6 J.
The change in internal energy of the gas from state B to state C is calculated as ΔU_B = nRT_B - nRT_C = (3 x 10^-3 m^3)(3 x 10^-5 Pa)(300 K) - (2.5 x 10^-3 m^3)(3 x 10^-5 Pa)(300 K) = 1.5 x 10^-6 J.
The total work done by the gas is the sum of changes in internal energy, ΔU = ΔU_A + ΔU_B = 1.5 x 10^-6 J + 1.5 x 10^-6 J = 3 x 10^-6 J.
Therefore, the work done by the gas from state B to state C is 3 x 10^-6 J.
